{{ NCAATeamSeason | Mode = football | Year = 1980 | Team = Nebraska Cornhuskers | Logo = University-of-Nebraska-Lincoln-logo.svg | LogoSize = 59 | Image = | ImageSize = | ImageAlt = | Conference = Big Eight Conference | Division = | ShortConference = Big 8 | BCSRank = | CoachRank = 7 | APRank = 7 | Record = 10-2-0 | ConfRecord = 6-1-0 | WinsVacated = | WinsForfeited = | ConfWinsVacated = | ConfWinsForfeited = | HeadCoach = [[Tom Osborne]] | HCYear = 8th | OffCoach = Tom Osborne | OCYear = 11th | DefCoach = Lance Van Zandt | DCYear = 4th | OScheme = [[I formation]] | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] | Champion = Sun Bowl Champions | BowlTourney = {{Alternate links|1980 Sun Bowl|Sun Bowl|title=Sun Bowl|alt=Sun Bowl}} vs. #17 {{cfb link|year=1980|school=Mississippi State University|team=Mississippi State Bulldogs|title=Mississippi State}} | BowlTourneyResult = W 31-17 | ConfChamp = | ConfChampResult = }} {{1980 Big 8 football standings}} The '''1980 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team''' represented the [[University of NebraskaâLincoln]] in the [[1980 NCAA Division I-A football season]]. The team was coached by [[Tom Osborne]] and played their home games in [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] in [[Lincoln, Nebraska]]. ==Schedule== {{Cite web |url=http://www.huskers.com/SportSelect.dbml?SPSID=3&SPID=22&DB_OEM_ID=100&KEY=&Q_SEASON=1980 |title =Football - 1980 Schedule/Results |accessdate=2009-06-04 |publisher=University of Nebraska-Lincoln |- | colspan="5" valign="bottom" align="right" |       |} ==Coaching staff== {| class="wikitable" |- |align="left"|'''Name'''||align="left"|'''Title'''||align="center"|'''First year
in this position''' ||align="center"|'''Years at Nebraska''' ||align="left"|'''Alma Mater''' |- |'''[[Tom Osborne]]'''|||Head Coach
Offensive Coordinator||align="center"|1973||align="center"|1964-1997||[[Hastings College]] |- |'''Lance Van Zandt'''|||Defensive Coordinator
Defensive Backs||align="center"|1977||align="center"|1977-1980||[[Lamar University|Lamar]] |- |'''Charlie McBride'''|||Defensive Line||align="center"|1977||align="center"|1977-1999||[[University of Colorado at Boulder|Colorado]] |- |'''Cletus Fischer'''|||Offensive Line||align="center"| ||align="center"|1960-1985||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''John Melton'''|||Tight Ends
Wingbacks||align="center"|1973||align="center"|1962-1988||[[University of Wyoming|Wyoming]] |- |'''Mike Corgan'''|||Running Backs||align="center"|1962||align="center"|1962-1982||[[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]] |- |'''Boyd Epley'''|||Head Strength Coach||align="center"|1969||align="center"|1969-2003||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''George Darlington'''|||Defensive Backs||align="center"| ||align="center"|1973-2002|| [[Rutgers University|Rutgers]] |- |'''Milt Tenopir'''|||Offensive Line||align="center"|1974||align="center"|1974-2002|| [[Sterling College (Kansas)|Sterling]] |- |'''Gene Huey'''|||Receivers||align="center"|1977||align="center"|1977-1986||[[University of Wyoming|Wyoming]] |- |'''[[Frank Solich]]'''|||Head Freshman Coach||align="center"|1979||align="center"|1979-2003||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''Jack Pierce'''||| ||align="center"| ||align="center"|1979-1991|| |- |'''[[Jerry Pettibone]]'''|||Recruiting Coordinator||align="center"|1980||align="center"|1980-1981||[[Oregon State University|Oregon State]] |} ==Game notes== ===Utah=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Utah at #8 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = [[1980 Utah Utes football team|Utah]] | Host = '''#8 Nebraska''' | V1 = 3| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 6 | H1 = 14| H2 = 7| H3 = 20| H4 = 14 | Date = 1980-09-13 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 75,526 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska racked up 545 yards on the ground, the second-highest total in school history, as IB [[Jarvis Redwine]] averaged over 10 yards per carry before leaving the game in the hands of capable reserves. Utah suffered from two interceptions, and the sole Utes touchdown didn't get punched in until Cornhusker backups were on the field in the 4th quarter for playing time. {{-}} ===Iowa=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Iowa at #6 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = [[1980 Iowa Hawkeyes football team|Iowa]] | Host = '''#6 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 14| H2 = 21| H3 = 7| H4 = 15 | Date = 1980-09-20 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,029 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska completely shut down Iowa's heralded runner Jeff Brown, putting to rest Iowa's hope for a rushing contest with Nebraska IB [[Jarvis Redwine]]. Redwine left the game shortly after halftime after collecting 153 yards on 12 attempts, while Brown added only 51 to his career total during the entire game. Other Iowa rushing attempts went the other way, and the Hawkeye ground total netted only 44 yards as the Cornhuskers allowed Iowa into Nebraska territory only twice in the entire game on their way to delivering a painful 57-0 shutout. {{-}} ===Penn State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#3 Nebraska at #11 Penn State''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#3 Nebraska''' | Host = #11 [[1980 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]] | V1 = 7| V2 = 7| V3 = 7| V4 = 0 | H1 = 0| H2 = 7| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1980-09-27 | Location = [[Beaver Stadium]], [[University Park, Pennsylvania]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 84,585 }} {{AFB game box end}} The [[Blackshirts (football)|Blackshirts]] were the stars of this day in front of a record crowd at College Station, as the Nebraska defense sacked Penn State QB [[Jeff Hostetler]] eight times for 89 yards, and forced seven turnovers, keeping the Nittany Lions constantly on their heels and away from any hope of an upset. Penn State managed just one touchdown, in the 2nd quarter, and accumulated a net rushing total of only 33 yards. {{-}} ===Florida State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#16 Florida State at #3 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#16 {{cfb link|year=1980|school=Florida State University|team=Florida State Seminoles|title=Florida State}}''' | Host = #3 Nebraska | V1 = 0| V2 = 3| V3 = 12| V4 = 3 | H1 = 7| H2 = 7| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1980-10-04 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,152 }} {{AFB game box end}} Trailing by 4 points as the clock wound down under 15 seconds, Nebraska QB Jeff Quinn was hit only three yards from the end zone, forcing a fumble which was recovered by Florida State. The Seminoles escaped Lincoln with a win, and the Cornhuskers lost IB [[Jarvis Redwine]] for two weeks due to broken ribs, along with their hopes for an undefeated season. {{-}} ===Kansas=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#10 Nebraska at Kansas''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#10 Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1980|school=University of Kansas|team=Kansas Jayhawks|title=Kansas}} | V1 = 7| V2 = 26| V3 = 14| V4 = 7 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1980-10-11 | Location = [[University of Kansas Memorial Stadium|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lawrence, Kansas]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 52,500 }} {{AFB game box end}} The temporary loss of IB [[Jarvis Redwine]] to injury presented no difficulties to the Big Red Machine, as Nebraska steamrolled Kansas in Lawrence, chalking up 33 points in the 1st half alone. By the end of the game, the [[Blackshirts (football)|Blackshirts]] had posted another shutout to their stats while the Cornhusker offense rolled up 520 yards of offense and 54 points. {{-}} ===Oklahoma State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Oklahoma State at #10 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1980|school=Oklahoma State University-Stillwater|team=Oklahoma State Cowboys|title=Oklahoma State}} | Host = '''#10 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 7| V4 = 0 | H1 = 14| H2 = 7| H3 = 14| H4 = 13 | Date = 1980-10-18 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,021 }} {{AFB game box end}} The Nebraska defense saw their string of touchdown-prevention quarters ended at 8 when Oklahoma State managed to squeak in a touchdown in the 3rd quarter, but that was all that would be heard from the Cowboys on this day since they were held to -13 ground yards compared to the 430 ground yards posted by the Cornhuskers. {{-}} ===Colorado=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#9 Nebraska at Colorado''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#9 Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1980|school=University of Colorado at Boulder|team=Colorado Buffaloes|title=Colorado}} | V1 = 7| V2 = 24| V3 = 7| V4 = 7 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 7 | Date = 1980-10-25 | Location = [[Folsom Field]], [[Boulder, Colorado]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 51,489 }} {{AFB game box end}} The return of Nebraska IB [[Jarvis Redwine]] was short-lived, as both he and 2nd string IB Craig Johnson left the game with injuries in the 1st quarter. 3rd string IB [[Roger Craig (American football)|Roger Craig]] was still too much for Colorado as Nebraska swept up the Buffaloes in Boulder while collecting 403 ground yards and a decisive 45-7 win, the 13th Cornhusker win in a row over Colorado, whose only score came in the 4th quarter against Nebraska reserves. {{-}} ===Missouri=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#15 Missouri at #8 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = #15 {{cfb link|year=1980|school=University of Missouri|team=Missouri Tigers|title=Missouri}} | Host = '''#8 Nebraska''' | V1 = 3| V2 = 10| V3 = 0| V4 = 3 | H1 = 14| H2 = 14| H3 = 0| H4 = 10 | Date = 1980-11-01 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,155 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska created a 15 point lead by halftime and never looked back, though Missouri was not to be trifled with. Where the Cornhuskers made their gains on the ground, the Tigers achieved their yards in the air, but at the end of the game it was still the Cornhuskers well ahead and celebrating their first win over Missouri in Memorial Stadium since 1972. {{-}} ===Kansas State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Kansas State at #5 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = [[1980 Kansas State Wildcats football team|Kansas State]] | Host = '''#5 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 8 | H1 = 10| H2 = 24| H3 = 14| H4 = 7 | Date = 1980-11-08 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,121 }} {{AFB game box end}} Kansas State was demolished in Lincoln in every way, as Nebraska racked up 495 yards on the ground and pushed both the 1st and 2nd string Wildcat quarterbacks backwards for a combined -67 yard net on the day. The normally ground-oriented Cornhuskers also dominated in the air, nearly doubling the Wildcat passing yard total and bringing the Nebraska yardage total to 695. Kansas State scored a single touchdown and capped it with a two point conversion with just 1:52 left on the clock in garbage time, narrowly avoiding the shutout. {{-}} ===Iowa State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#4 Nebraska at Iowa State''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#4 Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1980|school=Iowa State University|team=Iowa State Cyclones|title=Iowa State}} | V1 = 7| V2 = 7| V3 = 14| V4 = 7 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1980-11-15 | Location = [[Jack Trice Stadium|Cyclone Stadium]], [[Ames, Iowa]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 52,942 }} {{AFB game box end}} Compared with the week prior, Nebraska had a slow start, leading by only 14 at the half, and that only when a Cornhusker punt was fumbled by the Cyclone returner into the end zone and recovered by the Cornhuskers to add 7 to the total with 2:28 left in the half. Nonetheless, the Nebraska offense simply kept powering along, wearing down the Iowa State squad until they surrendered another 21 points, while the [[Blackshirts (football)|Blackshirts]] held the Cyclone offense to just 130 total yards and no points. {{-}} ===Oklahoma=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#9 Oklahoma at #4 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#9 [[1980 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]]''' | Host = #4 Nebraska | V1 = 0| V2 = 14| V3 = 0| V4 = 7 | H1 = 10| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 7 | Date = 1980-11-22 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,322 }} {{AFB game box end}} The Cornhuskers had a promising start, as IB [[Jarvis Redwine]] tore the Sooner defense for an 89 yard touchdown run on Nebraska's first possession and PK Kevin Seibel put a 47 yarder through the uprights to go up by 10, but Oklahoma came to life to lead 14-10 by halftime. Nebraska held the Oklahoma wishbone attack to just 7 yards in the 3rd quarter, but also gave up a couple of turnovers which proved costly as both teams put up only another touchdown each before the game was over with Oklahoma still up by 4 to claim the Big 8 title. {{-}} ===Mississippi State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#8 Nebraska vs #17 Mississippi State''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#8 Nebraska''' | Host = #17 {{cfb link|year=1980|school=Mississippi State University|team=Mississippi State Bulldogs|title=Mississippi State}} | V1 = 7| V2 = 10| V3 = 7| V4 = 7 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 3| H4 = 14 | Date = 1980-12-27 | Location = [[Sun Bowl Stadium]], [[El Paso, Texas]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 34,723 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska marked their 12th consecutive bowl game appearance by striking first with 7 points only 2:30 into the 1st quarter. It was not a major record-setting day, but consistent production and solid ball control provided the Cornhuskers with ample opportunites to produce points. The Bulldogs found themselves behind 17-0 at the half and never had an opportunity to make any serious threat to the Cornhuskers again. {{-}} ==Rankings== {{seealso|1980 NCAA Division I-A football rankings}} {| class="wikitable" style="white-space:nowrap;" |+ Ranking Movement |- !
